Fields.DialogueText: Huh.

Fields.MenuText: That's not something you see on a battleship every day... What is it, a doll of some kind?
I didn't know you played with dolls, Kongou.
Aren't you a little old to be playing with dolls?

Fields.DialogueText: This? Just a tool that I found useful in my uniform design project. You can be forgiven for mistaking it for a doll, Kanchou, it's actually a half scale dress form.
I don't think I'd call it play, Kanchou. Dress-up perhaps, but not play. Although based on its size, you can be forgiven for mistaking it for a bunraku puppet.
Kanchou, It seems I need to educate you before the next Hinamatsuri. In any event, this is more a small manikin than a doll.
An astute observer once wrote: "The clothing of a woman is a pleasure for the eye that cannot be judged inferior to the other arts." I couldn't agree more.
But the clothing of a woman isn't a static art, it's a performance. How a woman moves in - and with - a garment and accoutrements is the art.
This is my equivalent of a drafters table; a form on which to experiment on a small, simple scale that still takes physics into account.
Physics?
The way gravity pulls and air currents push fabric... the way it flows, even as the wearer stands still.
It's wishful thinking to believe a Chanel evening gown illustrated in Vogue actually looks that way on anyone.
Thank goodness for photos, then.
Not necessarily, Kanchou. Not if the design is intended for the camera and not the wearer. After all, Hollywood may showcase glamorous chic, but not every lady on earth is a Joan Crawford.
Gotcha. But now I'm curious, Kongou... I know you put all that thought - and more - into your uniform designs. Did you ever get an answer what the issue was with them?
The Protection Fleet has too many body sizes and shapes in it. My uniform was intended to fit anyone - with some alteration post-issue.
But If that takes more time than the average sailor's make-and-mend time - and talent. Well, better luck next time.
And a subject for a later time. I'm detecting Funayūrei crossing my path!
I'll meet you on the bridge, then.
@BATTLE
Kongou, I've been meaning to ask you about something.
Then don't hesitate, Kanchou. What are you curious about?
It occurs to me that you don't wear a sword.
Ah! And you're curious why I carry no blade, while a great many of my peers in service to the Imperial Japanese Navy do.
Is there any particular reason why?

Fields.MenuText: If it's because you don't feel you've earned the right yet or something, let me put that thought firmly to rest.
You are all about accessories, after all...
I'm sure it's within your right, so I figure the only reason that you don't wear one is because you choose not to.

Fields.DialogueText: So long as Terrors still squat within the Maelstroms, I haven't truly earned my spurs yet... but I acknowledge that I could wear a blade if I chose to.
Absolutely. But as with all things, one must take the considerations of time, place, and occasion into account.
Which leaves you wondering why I would choose not to.
It seems to me that during the middle of hand-to-hand combat would be the logical time, place and occasion to carry one... So why?
I have a number of reasons, Kanchou. I suppose the easiest one to understand would simply be that I don't need one.
I guess you bringing the amount of guns you do to a sword fight does make a blade kind of unnecessary...
Ara ara... Normally, Morganas have poor timing. Shall I demonstrate for you now?

Fields.MenuText: Not necessary, Kongou. We've been through enough combat, so I've seen what you can do. I believe you.
Some other time maybe. We have places to be, remember?
Might as well. The cosmos will take a declaration like that as a challenge, but we should probably get your dose of karma now, rather than after it has had time to collect interest.

Fields.DialogueText: As you wish, Kanchou.
Indeed.
Oh ye of little faith, Kanchou.
@BATTLE
Well, in a word... yes.
A... tenmasen?
That's right, Kanchou.
Why do you need your own small boat? Is something wrong with the captain's gig?
Not at all.
Then you're going to have to walk me through this one, Kongou.
I'm called in to act as bridge between the Protection Fleet we sail for and the Belles who comprise it, which finds us in Lisbon's harbor frequently.
It would be a prime opportunity to showcase the craft of my people, and add a bit more polish to a trip from the wharf to my deck.

Fields.MenuText: You want to get a new boat just for Lisbon harbor excursions?
I suppose that the ferry ride to you is as much a place for first impressions as the dock.
Something that unique would also identify all on on board as VIPs. How do you counter it standing out during a surprise Morgana raid?

Fields.DialogueText: Don't be silly, Kanchou. It would be available to me to transport guests in any port we find ourselves in.
Exactly, Kanchou. I'm also not a small ship. In the time it takes me to wait for a berth on the docks, I could moor in the harbor, ferry in and out those we have business with, and be on our way.
The same way I would deal with any Morgana raid, Kanchou.
Let me think about your proposal. Is that fair?
If that is your decision. In the meantime... orders coming in addressed to us.
@BATTLE
Hmmm... Let me think this one over a bit. ...This one has promise... No... Ye Gods, no...
That's quite the stack of files there, Kongou. May I ask what you're up to?
I'm a little hurt, Kanchou. You sound as if you believe I'm always scheming.

Fields.MenuText: Of course you're not always scheming, Kongou. You only resort to scheming when you're not in charge.
Not all, Kongou. You're never idle.
If you never enlighten me, how can I see it as anything else?

Fields.DialogueText: Ha! Now you definitely wound me, Kanchou!
My mistake, Kanchou. Please accept my apology, then.
You have a point, Kanchou. You may be my kanchou, but it is rather unfair to expect you to be able to read the air, so to speak, in so short a time. My apologies.
I felt that it was high time to permanently replace my stewards. Given that you found my previous use of crew time disruptive...
Ah, yes. Having the flight officer translating Marie-Claire issues for you seemed a little out of his scope of work.
Yes. *Ahem.* Well... To prevent that in the future, I deemed it necessary that my next pair of stewards be capable of accomplishing such tasks.
That sounds like an excellent idea, Kongou. Carry on, then.
*ALARM*
Certainly. Combat first, however.
But of course.
@BATTLE
Kongou, I've given your idea of replacing the captain's gig with a craft of a more... traditional design some thought.
A standard issue gig is easier to repair and replace. Unless a dedicated boatwright was added to your permanent crew, the upkeep of something unique wouldn't be easy.
So, here's my counterproposal: we keep the boats we have, and transport a tenmasen to Lisbon. It would be kept in storage there, and be available for use by any Imperial Japanese Belle.
So it wouldn't be mine exclusively, and would only reside in Lisbon...
But you get to sign off on the design and it would still be available for pomp, ceremonies and a taste of home. Does that sound reasonable?
What if I found a dedicated boatwright to add to my permanent crew?

Fields.MenuText: We'd cross that bridge if we came to it. And if you could find one.
Please do, Kongou. It's not like we're going to be able to station the repairman in Lisbon, just for one boat.
Then you'd also need to find one for Fubuki, too. And Nenohi, and Takao, and-

Fields.DialogueText: Then consider it a matter of when, not if, Kanchou!
Consider it done, Kanchou.
Point taken, Kanchou.
I will... accept those terms. However, I reserve the right to continue to explore the idea of having such a boat for any port-of-call.
That, or a tenmasen in every major port...
All right then. Once we're done here, we can see about arranging a little trip to Yokosuka.
I look forward to it!
@BATTLE
Drapers Record... and tearing into the latest Vogue, I see.
Someone must. "It would be an added calamity if war turned England into a nation of frights and slovens...?"
... In the evening a woman should be "as mysterious, alluring, witty, veiled, gloved, corseted and even button-booted as any romantic, fairytale queen...?!"

Fields.MenuText: There's the problem right there, Kongou.
It sounds to me like England is doomed if the only choices are "romantic, fairytale queen" or "not romantic fairytale queen enough."
Well, Kongou, aside from the veiled, corseted and and even button-booted part, you have the look down pat - day or night - if you ask me.

Fields.DialogueText: Better yet, do me a favor and start stockpiling all the mystery, allure and wit you can.
Couldn't agree more, Kanchou.
You are generous with your compliments, Kanchou. The "romantic fairytale queen" usually doesn't carry enough firepower to personally defend her realm from the Black Knight, however.
So you think the fashion world is out of touch with the times. Have you ever considered submitting your own designs?
Not since my uniform proposal, no. It took considerable effort to prepare what I did, and the Protection Fleet wasn't enlightened enough for my designs.
I doubt the houses of haute couture would be any more receptive to my sense of style.
Probably not.
@BATTLE
I see nothing wrong with your elegance-in-arms look either. You aren't a staunch defender of corsets, then... I'll remember that.
That, and her corset would be the greater foe.
Let us meet in battle, and come out victorious.
@BATTLE
Kongou, please don't sulk.
I believe I'm perfectly entitled to sulk when I must cancel a soirée for lack of participants... especially after I predicted I would have to.
Of course no one from Tokyo would travel to Yokosuka if there was a chance I could be called back out to sea! This is precisely why I requested our final destination be closer to Minato!
Yet you still want to be on standby.

Fields.MenuText: You can't have it both ways, Kongou.
I'm sure there will be other times when your guests won't worry about you deploying out from under them.
I know you could pull off a party on short notice, but wouldn't you be happier with a little more time for preparation?

Fields.DialogueText: And why not? With my speed, does it really make a difference whether I'm moored closer to Sumida-gawa or Futtsu-misaki?
I'm sure you're right, Kanchou. It doesn't take the sting out of it however.
You have a point, Kanchou. Just a supper at anchor would probably be misinterpreted as a longer visit cut short, and create more anxiety than it would allay.
Sigh... I suppose I will have to content myself with breaking in my new stewards.
Not literally, I hope.
Maybe not. It would make even less of a difference if we could just run over every boat between us and the Pacific on the way out, too, and not worry about incident reports...
You've made your point, Kanchou.
I'm sure it doesn't. Not that you need any, but add Sufficient Hosting Time to the list of incentives for keeping the seas clear of Morganas.
Consider it done.
No.
Kanchou, I don't understand why not. After all, we're only going to Nagoya.
That's if a Morgana fleet doesn't show up. And I'm still a little fuzzy on the reason why we need to make the trip to Nagoya in the first place.
To select a boat builder. I have but one opportunity to have a proper boat built, yes? It would be sheer folly to simply commission the first master I can get my hands on.
In addition, the waterways of the Empire are teeming with exquisite boats of many designs.
I don't wish to come away from Osaka Bay or Kammon-kaikyo later with regrets, simply because I made a hasty decision in Tokyo Bay.
Okay, the planning I can understand. But the need to go to them, instead of the other way around?
You're expecting a busy master boatwright to leave the workshop, Kanchou. I get farther from my hull than some of them from their workspace.
Something a resume with pictures of their past work could help with... but nothing beats a face-to-face interview, I guess.
That still doesn't change my mind about not leaving one of your floatplanes here so that your stewards can be left behind.

Fields.MenuText: Those are your eyes, Kongou. A 33% loss of sight is too much to give up, even temporarily.
Think of it as the perfect opportunity for them to pick up some souvenirs for you on the train ride to catch up with us in Nagoya.
If you can't get your shopping done while in port, I suggest you think about mail order.

Fields.DialogueText: That may be true, but these are home waters for me. I have the benefit of surveillance from land-based aerocraft on my side.
It's because they didn't get what I wanted in the first place that I'm making the request. It's far too soon to test their abilities with a souvenir trip omakase.
An understandable request, Kanchou, and certainly a method that I use when what I seek isn't fragile, perishable, unique, or timely.
Well, we do have some time left before we cast off the mooring lines. Let me see what I can do. I make no promises, but maybe the base or another ship can lend us a floatplane taxi.
My sincere gratitude to you knows no bounds, Kanchou.
@BATTLE
You have a point.
I would have even proposed transporting them by such means, but...
But?
As you pointed out, I can't be sure that somewhere along the way I won't find a Morgana or two seeking to be perforated.
Which would cancel this cruise to Nagoya and definitely make it harder for my stewards to get back without float plane or boat assistance.
This would be an even bigger study of frustration if mail order was my only means of acquisition.
Let us meet in battle, and come out victorious.
@BATTLE
As I thought, Breaking Waves was the ideal motif...
You know, Kongou, when I heard this was about a commissioned folding fan I assumed you were getting something more sturdy.
Oh, you mean such as a tessen, Kanchou? While it's true I intend to use this for night operations, my goal was never for it to be a weapon, but an accessory.
I'd rather obscure my identity with a fan than with makeup... I'll leave kesho to the kabuki stage.
So you don't see yourself ever using a tessen.
Not if it limits my choices, no. After all, a well-planned wardrobe is one with accessories that complement a spectrum of outfits rather than a single one.

Fields.MenuText: The same way a well-designed deck arrangement allows your secondary and tertiary armament to complement each other better?
That is a surprise. I didn't think you worried about budget, where your wardrobe is concerned.
I'm sure you could find enough tasteful ones to still cover your wardrobe needs if you put your mind to it.

Fields.DialogueText: An interesting analogy, Kanchou.
It's only common sense, Kanchou. A large budget should yield an even more flexible wardrobe, not less.
That's quite true, Kanchou. But in addition to making Funayūrei regret their miserable existences, I also entertain civilians. Being too armed at all times can send the wrong message.
To all things there is a season. More often than not, a fan of ivory or awabi makes my desired impression even better than one of steel.
I see.
Besides, a tessen is unnecessary when the fan case that enshrouds it is made of gilded belt armor.
That may sound sensible, Kongou, but there are people with more money than sense.
Like "There's no safety from attack at any time, anywhere." or  "There is no hope." Or "I don't believe the local forces are doing their job well enough to protect you!"
Or that combat is the only language I know.
Kongou, what are you doing?
At the risk of being flippant, Kanchou, what anyone with a wireless radio transmitter and binoculars would be doing up in the mast lookout position.
Ah! *click* The one off your starboard beam, not midships! Over! *click*
Usually, a spotter would be on lookout, or calling down results to fire control... not directing stewards to the shops she wants them to hit.
It's what comes from having people that haven't absorbed enough to intuit what interests me.

Fields.MenuText: Look on the bright side, Kongou... Your stewards may stumble across something you didn't even know you were looking for.
Sounds as if you need to add radio operation to the list of skills your stewards need.
I'm almost afraid to hear the answer, but what equipment are they using? They aren't carting around a radio gutted from one of your floatplanes, are they?

Fields.DialogueText: You may have a point, Kanchou. As expected, you're able to cut right to the cloud's silver lining.
One skill of many on a long list.
Disable one of my own floatplanes for such an excursion? Don't be silly, Kanchou.
You know, from time to time I do go ashore. If you let me know what you were looking for...
It's most generous of you to offer, but I couldn't do that, Kanchou. Your time ashore shouldn't be wasted on the whims of this old ship.
Let me be the judge of-
Were you going ashore for something in particular? I can have my people see to it while on their return.
Not if you're recalling them because duty calls.
@BATTLE
Oh good...for a minute there, I was worried.
They're testing the spare one.
Kongou, I remember you saying that your uniform proposal was thorough enough to include dress uniforms. What conclusion did you reach about dress swords and the Fleet?
That's a tangle of Gordian proportions, Kanchou. Not even Tonbokiri could cut to a satisfactory answer on that subject.
But you came to some sort of answer.
Of a sort. A recommendation, at best. Fleet kanchous would still bear the naval dress sword of their home fleet and Belles, that of the navy of the ensign she flies.
So, no cutlass for you, then. But, that doesn't sound very controversial...
True. It's how the sword would be worn where the details get devilish.
My thought had been with a baldric in Neutrality stripe tri-colours. A way to separate Neutrality Fleet kanchous from those outside it, and coordinate a Belle with her own kanchou.

Fields.MenuText: And a way to carry one without having to design a sword belt that goes with everything.
So that's how you were going to get out of wearing a sword belt with a formal kimono.
A nice touch, but I would like to think I don't need anything to visually identify myself as a member of the Neutrality Fleet. I'd hope that a Belle at my side would say it all.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, I could have suggested a cummerbund approach to the issue, Kanchou. Bear in mind however, how sticky a problem a simple striped undershirt was for the enlisted...
A cummerbund would have done the same thing, Kanchou. But in the name of ceremony I may be called on to disarm, and therefore decided to pursue a means to do so smoothly and with dignity.
Don't get me wrong, Kanchou. I believe you to be a kanchou among kanchous, and it fills me with pride to be your ship.
Incidentally, what kind of dress sword would you wear? There are plenty of options.
I'm partial to a kyu-gunto of stainless steel, I suppose.
Really? You're less of a traditionalist than I thought. So no katana of ancient pedigree, then.
They're too prone to rust as it is. The sea is no place for a Nihonto.
You were willing to stave off oxidation rather than get your hull repainted, but a sharpened bar of steel is too much trouble?
Yet you said so yourself - would it be worth the amount of concentration I would have to constantly give one, when a blade of modern alloy would serve just as well?
I exist as a floating castle of steel, Kanchou. A more fitting tribute to the castles of earth, wood and stone that lined my flanks, and the samurai that clashed over them.
I see what you mean. But even taking that into account, why not a kai-gunto? They may not be as historical, but they look more Japanese than kyu-gunto do...
Very true. To the untrained eye, a kyu-gunto could be mistaken for a sabre of Western make. But it's also the style I personally have known longest.
Right, you do go back a bit...
Even more than you think, Kanchou. In any event, it really wouldn't matter either way. Dress swords hold little interest to me.
Because they aren't intended for combat?
Because they are swords. No one would bat an eye if a ship named after Poseidon lacked a blade on her hip...
... and carried a BIG trident instead. In that case, Kongou, what does a battleship named after a mountain named after the vajra carry? Lightning in a bottle?
A kongousho.
Or two.
Kanchou?
You gave your name to your ship class, Kongou. You have one for that, too.
You know me well.
An able hawk conceals her talons, Kanchou. Now, if you'll excuse me...
And I'm back to square one.
@BATTLE
Right. We're talking officers - no matter how universal you designed it, somebody's illustrious tradition was going to get slighted.
If the whole thing were removed, as I intended, the baldric even provides a cloth layer to protect the saya - the scabbard - from unnecessary scratches when set down.
You think there's even a chance you'd ever be willing to disarm, Kongou? I'm amazed.
Why certainly, Kanchou. If it was at His Imperial Majesty's request, it goes without saying.
And if under someone else's guns?
You are my kanchou, so ultimately the decision would be yours.
That said, my preference is for the only arms I offer anyone under those circumstances be the fragments they dredge up from my carcass.
I hear you, Kongou.
Not all members of Neutrality Fleet have the... presence you have, however.
Flatterer.
I would be if my praise wasn't sincere and heartfelt.
Then I thank you for the compliment.
Let us meet in battle, and come out victorious.
@BATTLE
I don't think I've ever seen a courier clear the deck so fast in my life.
She needn't have worried. It's not the messenger that displeases me.
But those look like invitations.
They are. This one's for me, the other probably for you. For a dinner... downtown.
Knowing full well that this place isn't big enough to host two high-class events on the same night.
Knowing damn well that I do not attend events beyond pierside! It's why I so frequently play hostess to such things!

Fields.MenuText: Someone has a lot of nerve. Hand over my invitation, Kongou - I'll tear it up myself.
And here I thought pitched battle was vicious and cutthroat. What's the plan?
That's too bad. ... Don't wait up for me, then.

Fields.DialogueText: Don't do that, Kanchou! Now you must go.
First, I need to make some discreet inquiries, to determine if this has happened to other Belles who make this their port of call.
Have a good time, Kanchou.
It's out of the question to offer to provide the setting for someone else's gala, I take it.
Indeed.
Well, it looks like I have some preparations to make.
... So do I, Kanchou. So do I.
I don't get it.
You need to convey my deep regret that my limitations prevent me from attending. Otherwise...
Otherwise, to everyone else it'll look like you intentionally snubbed the invitation. I get it now.
It's one thing if I alone am being slighted and quite another if we Belles of the Fleet are being consciously denied access to certain circles.
Either way, I'll deliver your message.
That's not-
Necessary? Your response will carry more weight if I deliver it. Besides, I saw the courier that came to you, Kongou. I'd be a coward if I left it to one of your stewards.
I see. Rest assured, you are no coward, Kanchou. Nevertheless... I'll bear in mind who the messenger is when I compose it.
I appreciate that. ...This probably goes without saying, but just to let it be said...
Really?
Certainly. I'll even see to it one of my stewards is your chauffeur, so that you can enjoy yourself to the fullest extent.
That would be a thoughtful gesture, Kongou, if I didn't know you'll also have your steward take notes.
How else am I supposed to stage a bigger, better event the day after?
Ah yes, let planning for the retaliatory shindig commence and prepare to let slip the caterers of war.
Kongou... Kongou, wait up...
Is there something wrong, Kanchou?
I just got word you requested permission from the OOD to disembark.
Indeed.
You usually aren't so formal about it.
True. Being a kami does have certain advantages, and usually I see no reason to bother the OOD every time I want to materialize over on the pier to inspect my moorings and such.
However, I have decided that now is the perfect opportunity to find not only a suitable gift to celebrate Hiei's return to active duty, but omiyage for Kirishima and Haruna.
So you're going out. On your own.
That is my intention...
Kongou, the nearest shops are blocks away.

Fields.MenuText: I didn't think it was possible for you Belles to go more than ten yards out. Did something change recently?
Have one of your stewards drive you, at least. It's a little faster than walking and you're liable to scare the hell out of the locals if you just appear out of thin air.
This ought to be good...

Fields.DialogueText: Yes, Kanchou - I made a resolution to expand my horizons.
Hmmm... You may be underestimating my speed and range, Kanchou, but I can see your point about potentially frightening those unfamiliar with Belles.
Scoff all you want, Kanchou. I'm walking.
Hmph!
Kongou?
That...may take...me...some...time...
Are you all right? You're not making much forward progress.
This... may take longer than I thought.
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
Okaaay... Kongou, while I respect your generosity and... independence... I have to ask if this trip is really necessary.
Absolutely. I know there are rumors that my joy with Hiei's return has everything to do with the entire family, one and all, finally being rated as fast battleships.
Really... when did she manage that?
When she acquiesced to being demilitarized during the treaty years. I'd surely have gnawed off my anchor-chains and begged for the breaker's yard, had it been me.
I believe you. And I get that you want to pull out all the stops for this, but if it's dangerous...
Then I will find out.
You'll find... You mean you don't even know what will happen?
Indeed. Up until now I've had a...feeling that I should stay close to my hull. It's high time I challenge that feeling and see for myself what happens.
Here I go-
Kongou, Wait!
It couldn't be farther from the truth. I am very fond of my younger sister. We shared a great deal of history together. She even saved my life, Kanchou.
Steward! Meet me at the Motorpool for chauffeur detail.
Aye-aye, Miss Kongou!
Will you allow me to accompany you? I do know how to keep a surprise gift a surprise...
A gracious gesture, Kanchou, but my plan had been to wander the shopping district until inspiration struck me.
Let us meet in battle, and come out victorious.
@BATTLE
Out in the middle of the harbor. Again.
Someone keeps sending misfortune my way. And when I find that someone....

Fields.MenuText: You'll probably find the Morganas in the way.
You feel targeted? Maybe it's raining on everybody.
I'll take up the collection right now for another miniature shrine. You know, to go next to the one you have for that pier's-worth of departed sea lions.

Fields.DialogueText: I do hope that's the case, Kanchou. I'd like nothing better than to kill two birds with one piece of ordinance.
Mountains cause rain and snow just by the virtue of being mountains. I'm no stranger to rain.
Tch! I'd forgotten about them...
Well, look on the bright side - you get to still play hostess. And being out here really does allow guests to take in your size and shape.
Yes, I suppose that's true...
Dockside, it's easy to overlook that you're a ship and not some floating harbor command center. Out here, there's no shadow of a doubt.
True. But it also means waiting to receive my guests, Kanchou.
And you aren't the most patient Belle in the Fleet.
Indeed. Which is why I intend to greet them at the dock, by going with the coxswain in a motorized launch to pick them up. I just won't leave the launch.
I didn't know you could do that. You can do that, right?
I ought to. As my own launch, it's part of my equipment, after all... and, logically, an extension of me.
So are your floatplanes... but if memory serves, you Belles lose contact with them as soon as they touch down. Isn't that the same for your boats, too?
Yes and no, Kanchou. My boats don't normally venture as far from me as my aerial reconnaissance does, so while I may not be connected exactly, I can... sense... them better.
I can tell which boats are mine, at any rate... and that should to be enough of a connection to serve.
We'll see.
Yes... well, the sooner I go, the sooner I can return with my guests. If you will excuse me...
What happened?
You couldn't tell?
Other than initially you were going nowhere, now you're back...
And usually a coxswain gets that much keel out of the water only when we're hauling that thing back on board. It's off like a shot, Kongou!
The launch was floating. Just enough to make the motor AND the waves meaningless.
Until you returned.
Sigh... If you'll excuse me, Kanchou, I think I need to do a walk-around inspection of my deck before my guests arrive.
Take your time.
I do not take kindly to anyone deliberately funneling moisture-laden air my way, however.
GET BACK HERE *Huff* YOU MISERABLE *Huff* PIECE OF *Huff* BOOT LEATHER! *Huff*... AND GLUE!
Easy, Kongou! Take it easy!
I *Huff* will not! I HAVE *Gasp* A BOW FOR A KOKYU WITH *Huff* YOUR NAME ON IT!

Fields.MenuText: Is this any way for the Belle of an Imperial Japanese Battleship to behave, Kongou? And on the docks, no less.
And there's a room in officer's territory with your name on it, Kongou. Do you want me to send you to it?
Kongou, please tell me what I can do to get you to take it down a notch from wrath of an angry god.

Fields.DialogueText: Imperial or not. Battleship or not. I will not be thwarted.
No, Kanchou. That will not be *Huff* necessary.
This is about a horse?
Certainly. I can't simply run in the National, now can I?
You mean the Grand National. As in that annual National Hunt. In Aintree.
That's right. Ah, I remember how the locals talked about them with excitement for weeks after the fact, when I was in Barrow.
It figures that you'd set your sights not only on a steeplechase, but the one with the longest course in Britain.
And enough obstacles to make completing the racecourse an accomplishment.
A true test of character. ...I thought my first obstacle would be learning to ride, however. But no, it's getting the bloody beast close enough to get in the saddle!
I'm going to go out on a limb here and guess "Boot Leather" has little-to-no military experience.
You may be frustrated by anything less than a seasoned warhorse, Kongou.
A warhorse?
Right. Even you have to admit that at your most cordial, you have a... presence... about you. I suspect you'd intimidate any horse that can't follow commands while shells are flying.
I see. I'll give that some thought. In the meantime, Kanchou, that's a Fleet courier inbound, unless I'm mistaken.
@BATTLE
Ambassador to the Fleet, or not? Even you have to admit, this doesn't sound the least bit diplomatic...
I have it on good authority that diplomacy is lost on horses...
Oh, good. Now, maybe you can take a breath or two and explain what brought you to the verge of a full salvo?
Well... actually... Ah! Kanchou, do you see those groomsmen, bringing that horse between them?
At this rate, I'm not sure we're going to convince crewmembers to return, much less whomever it is you're yelling at...
Not whom, Kanchou. What.
I'm listening...
A horse.
Let us meet in battle, and come out victorious.
@BATTLE
I see what you mean. And only the two of you and I know?
Yes, Captain.
Good work.
Kanchou! Had I known you were coming, I would have had tea prepared.
Start heating water and fetch the private settings. And that blend I just received from Algérie.
Understood, Miss Kongou.
This is a surprise. What brings you to my quarters, Kanchou?
Just a hunch. You haven't been out on the edge of your range lately, have you?
Well, I did take to the air above my mast earlier, in an effort to convince a flock of guano-laden gulls that my deck is not their privy...
I see.

Fields.MenuText: Kongou, I'd like your help. I need to get a look at the back of my head.
Kongou, we need to talk.
Have you looked in a mirror recently, Kongou?

Fields.DialogueText: Between the full length mirror and this compact, that should be easy enough to do.
Kanchou?
That's a rather odd question to ask, but no, I haven't. Is something wrong with the cut of my jib?
EGADS! I'm a mess!
That could've gone better...
I know it's an unusual request and everyone insists I look fine, but I really feel like I should have a look for myself.
Have no fear, I'd be happy to. Just stand over there... can you see now, Sen-
Take a look first, then you tell me.
Very well, if you insist...
I understand how impatient you can be on a good day, and I understand the distance you can get from your hull can feel like being under house arrest.
But recently you've been constantly on the edge of your range, and it's starting to take its toll on you.
That's nonsense, Kanchou. I feel perfectly fine.
You don't look it though. It's affecting your appearance.
My appearance? That's preposterous! I look... look...
Debussy's Prelude to the Afternoon of a Faun. But that's no flute I've ever seen before...
A gift from a guest I've entertained who also believes that Western music and Japanese traditions are not mutually exclusive.
Think of it as a metal shakuhachi with the key range of a flute... but you're not here to make small talk about my choice of music or talent with an okraulo.
No.
Kanchou, when you look to the docks... to the waves around me... do you see any physical obstacle that stands between me and my limit?
There is no wall, no moat. No minefield or fence. There's literally nothing standing between me and a step beyond it.
The limitation- the weakness- is in me, then. It's become a flaw that I cannot accept in myself.
Will not accept.
In this case it makes no difference.
But your range is a limitation not limited to you.
And there are Belles of the Fleet that accept it. I'm not one of them.

Fields.MenuText: I know that. You're in a class all by yourself in many ways, Kongou.
That doesn't change the fact that you're still a Belle.
Really. I hadn't noticed.

Fields.DialogueText: I have been told that before, and not always as a compliment.
My "body" isn't so much weak, Kanchou, as it is over thirty thousand tonnes and decidedly not designed to be amphibious.
Since you aren't the only Belle chafing like this, Kongou, do me a favor. Before you pound your head against the proverbial wall again, ask around the network you Belles have.
At the very least, you can learn from others' attempts.
And avoid pitfalls already well-surveyed... Yes, I see. ... Ah ha!
Ideas already? That was fast.
My apologies, Kanchou, but it will take longer than that to get an inquiry out. In the meantime however, I've located Morgana targets in the vicinity.
@BATTLE
It's still true.
(Smiles) Fair enough.
I will also point out that my "body" was originally fueled with oil-mixed coal. I was gutted - twice! - in order to attain my modern oil-only boiler compliment.
Can we really compare my "spirit" and "body" to a human model? Because the conclusion then is that my "body" will never permit me to engage in activities beyond my range.
And such a conclusion is unacceptable.
I see your point.
Kanchou! As expected, you were right on the mark. The scuttlebutt is there's even a Belle doing her utmost to extend her range.
That's great news.
That's not great news?
It's very good news, Kanchou.
But.
Sigh... I haven't reached a point where I am satisfied with second place.

Fields.MenuText: Think of it less like a race, and more like standing on the shoulders of giants. You're no stranger to the giant's place...
There's nothing wrong with being in second place for now. You know that slow and steady wins this kind of thing, right?
There's nothing wrong with a little healthy competition, Kongou. Just remember that we're all on the same side.

Fields.DialogueText: You think I should be gracious then, and let someone else do the heavy lifting this time.
Slow and steady only wins when the swift lack stamina or focus - or both - and squander their advantage. Still, I suppose it couldn't hurt to draft in her wake.
You don't know some of the Belles in this Fleet very well, do you, Kanchou?
@BATTLE
You do get a lot of respect, Kongou. Respect that you deserve. No one's going to think poorly of you if you're not the first on this.
What if I am the one who'll think poorly of myself, then?
Then instead of putting all your effort into breaking the barrier first, why not build off someone else's work and focus instead on the way to do it smoothly and effortlessly at will?
Hmmm.... Yes, that does seem the greater challenge with this puzzle... So be it. I'll set about finding who the rumors are referring to, and learn what I can from her example.
I'll let you get to it, then.
Draft?
Precisely, Kanchou. The way six-day racers conserve their strength by riding in the leader's slip-stream, then sprint ahead at the last minute.
If it helps to think of it in those terms, then sure. Wait...
I don't need to worry about waking up one day to find you've turned the main deck into a velodrome, right?
You have nothing to fear.
Oh good.
Not when my casemate deck is sufficient.
Practice for a six-day should go a long way to keeping me preoccupied during my next refit.
Okay, I can't argue with that.
Still, I do understand the point you're trying to make - finding a means to extend our range would be a boon to us all.
And two heads are better than one. Unless your name is Delusion, anyway...
Very well. I shall monitor the progress of my fellow Belles and provide insight where I may.
In the meantime, I shall apply the lion's share of my competitive spirit to where it truly matters - the number of Morganas I put on the bottom.
Good to hear.
I thought I'd prepared myself for anything. But this!
Kongou, what's wrong? You sound like someone died. If one of your sisters...
What? No, no, Kanchou. I can account for my sisters. To a certain extent this is worse. My sisters are all made of stern materials and armed for war. Humans, however, are not so fortunate.
Then, the Emperor?
Were that to happen, I believe the very seas would weep at the lamentations of every kami of every Imperial vessel - Belle or not.
Right.

Fields.MenuText: Then can we cut to the chase, Kongou? What's got you so upset?

Fields.DialogueText: What has me upset is Madame Vionnet is retiring! I was aware she had closed Maison Vionnet, at the start of the war. She closed her doors before, during the Great War.
I suppose you're right to think I am in mourning. I imagine that's what it is - mourning the end of an era.
Flagons, Kanchou? My answer is none. If I must drink to the health and happiness of Madame Vionnet, it would be with something far more deserving of the privilege than mere plonk.
It's a wonder I keep up with her at all.
@BATTLE
Now however, rumors have reached me that she doesn't intend to return, even after the war!
So, this is about a fashion crisis.
Indeed - of the highest order!
But what am I doing, just standing here? We have a mission to complete... immediately! There's much to be done!
When word spread even before the arrival of the Morganas that Maison Vionnet was to close, I wasn't surprised. Madame Vionnet did the same thing during the Great War.
But...I couldn't conceive of her complete departure. I've received word from a trusted source that she intends to retire.
I see.
For many years, I've had a keen interest in the houses of haute couture in Paris. And now, when I can finally express that...
Now a star that shone brightly to me, even in that City of Light, is winking out.
You can still express yourself, Kongou. I bet she'd be flattered to get a letter or a telephone call from you.
A telephone! THAT'S IT! Thank you, Kanchou!
But I only meant-
Okay, now we're getting somewhere.
I only wish we were. If only there was some way to contact her, and convince her not to retire...
She's not allowed to retire?
Absolutely not. Fashion has declined precipitously as it is... for her to close up shop and permanently bow out now is a tragedy I must somehow avert!
Thank you, Kanchou. I see now what I must do.

Fields.MenuText: I'm listening. Are you in mourning?
Then on your flagon scale, what are we looking at here? Two flagons? Three?

Fields.DialogueText: Yes... yes... That's what I keep saying... I've been through this three times!
No... Yes, I'm quite aware there's a war going on. ... Because I'm KONGOU! What does it take to convince you?
That good, huh.
Well, it is an international call. She's being remarkably patient.
Do you even understand Japanese? Then what good would that do? If I recited a shopping list in Hawai'ian, would you even know the differ-
Hello?

Fields.MenuText: Would it have killed you to recite a haiku, or something?
Hawai'ian? That sounds like a pretty specific example to pull out of thin air, Kongou.
I guess fifth time's the charm.

Fields.DialogueText: The first eight times it didn't. Where I come from, even an Enlightened being has limits.
It's not a tongue I get many opportunities to use, Kanchou, but I can speak it.
Would that it was, Kanchou, but we're too close to departure. Missions come first, so contacting Madame Vionnet will have to wait.
If it didn't risk giving away our position, I'd let you continue to try at sea.
And give the Funayūrei a chance to easily find me? I'll let them have a hint of that when my shells reach them.
Then let's go give them some.
@BATTLE
At this rate, a telegraph or a letter might be the faster means to get your message across, Kongou.
Or have it lost any number of ways. To say nothing of her response... No, direct voice-to-voice contact is the only way I can be sure.
You know, she isn't the only designer in France, let alone the world. What are you hoping to gain by all of this?
Myself? Very little. Even if she were to reopen Maison Vionnet, her works are one of a kind.
As such, she prefers to advertise her fashions through the garments worn by her clientele, rather than journalists.
Right. Which would explain the request that floated across my desk recently, to permanently station one of your stewards in Paris.
Yes... well, it only makes logical sense, Kanchou.
Between the closure of Maison Vionnet and Mainbocher putting his tail between his legs and relocating to New York, I fear the seat of haute couture will collapse like the stock market.
That sounds rather ghoulish, if you ask me.
Perhaps. I prefer to see it as preserving what I can, so that kernels of new ideas are not lost and may last long enough to emerge on the other side of this conflict.
New fabrics came out of the Great War, but that is hardly compensation for the untold ideas that never saw the light of day.
Yeah, creativity for creativity's sake does kind of take a back seat to survival. That doesn't answer my question though.
It may be better to ask what I - and the world, for that matter - stand to lose with her retirement. We lose a fearless vanguard of the avant-garde since before the Great War.
We lose the apparent simplicity of her garments, that belie their masterful construction.
Her mission to free both fabric and figure from Western fashion sensibilities cannot be stressed enough, I think. Do you remember my miniature manikin, from before?
It's my humble attempt to emulate a genius' technique.
That's high praise, coming from you. Does she know the Fleet has an admirer of hers?
I don't know. Madame Vionnet is a very private person... It was no easy task to find a telephone number where she could be reached.
Which reminds me... I need to brush up on my cricket.
Cricket?
The price I paid for that information. There's a French Belle setting up a match, and I believe she plans to use me as a ringer.
Have fun with that.
Oh, I shall. Excuse me, Kanchou.
Time for me to get to work then...
Well, aren't you full of surprises.
It would appear not nearly enough, since I'm no closer to contacting Madame now than I was four attempts ago.
I appreciate your dedication, Kongou. And your discretion.
Hmm.
Kanchou, about our orders and course...

Fields.MenuText: So you noticed? Well, it was only a little out of our way, and I figured since we were in the neighborhood...
Is there a problem, Kongou? I thought you lived for these dangerous attack missions.
I should've known there's no getting things past you, Kongou. And here I thought I'd get to keep things a secret for a little while longer.

Fields.DialogueText: Not that I mind, but this is more than just a little out of our way. And I suspect this isn't the last mission we'll just happen to be "in the neighborhood" for... all the way to France.
I do indeed. But I also happen to notice a distinct trend in the direction of said attack missions.
You could only keep our ultimate destination a mystery but so long.
While I'm not averse to being able to make a telephone call to Madame Vionnet without the added international pitfalls, I still feel the need to ask -- why?
It's important to you to speak with her, right? Who knows... There's a better chance of arranging a face-to-face if you're in France.
At the risk of sounding pessimistic, Kanchou, that's not possible. Maison Vionnet is on the Champs-Élysées. The farthest this old ship can get up the Seine is to Rouen, much less Paris.
You're aware of my range. It's impossible for me to go to her.
If the mountain can't come to Madame Vionnet, why can't Madame Vionnet come to the mountain? Unless...
Indeed. We've been near enough when in Lisbon, that I've sent her invitations to visit me. I even offered to transport her with a floatplane of my own.
This is the first time I've heard about it.
Because it came to naught. Her response was very polite, but as I mentioned before, she is a very private person.
So she hasn't left her shop since she reopened after the Great War?
I didn't say that, Kanchou. She had a short-lived boutique in Biarritz...
Biarritz, hm? Kongou, I'm going to pull captain's prerogative, and commandeer your stewards.
@BATTLE
It has me conflicted, Kanchou. I don't know whether to hope the Morganas are smart enough to connect the dots and predict where we're going, or hope they're too stupid.
My advice is to hope they're smart enough, so we can catch all of them at once and be left with just the stupid ones.
You're ever the font of strategic wisdom, Kanchou.
Let us meet in battle, and come out victorious.
@BATTLE
Do you really think a translator is necessary, Kongou?
I know your French wasn't that bad to begin with, and you've got your stewards doing more than simply translating your fashion magazines for you.
Don't you need one, Kanchou?

Fields.MenuText: Good point.
(I speak French very well, thank you very much!) You're not doing this for me, Kongou, and you know it.
You bet, Kongou - but I know even the best translator in the world won't help me as soon as you two start talking fashion.

Fields.DialogueText: It would be the height of rudeness to leave you out of the conversation completely, especially after all you've done to facilitate this meeting.
I told you before, didn't I? The able hawk conceals her talons. I'll know what she is saying as she says it, and can use the translation time to formulate my response.
Yet in spite of that, you've made this meeting a reality. You have my deepest gratitude.
Here they come now.
Welcome, Madame Vionnet. I hope your train ride here wasn't too adventurous.
*whisper*
*whisper*
"Kanchou. Between receiving the hand-delivered invitation of a captain of a Fleet vessel and being smuggled out of Paris, the trip itself was anticlimactic."
Smuggled?
At her request, Captain. Madame is currently "under the weather" and has returned to her bed. My colleague is maintaining that illusion for Madame.
*whisper*
"I didn't want anyone to know I'm gone. I'm not a" ...um... "rat deserting a sinking ship."
So long as it was your idea and you weren't put at risk in the process, I have no issue with it. I'd like to introduce you to the Belle of my ship - this is Kongou.
It is a pleasure to meet you, Madame.
*whisper*
*whisper*
"So this is the Mighty Kongou. The pleasure is mine."
You may have me confused with someone else, Madame...
It also gives you the opportunity to understand her and have time to come up with your answer.
You make it sound like that's a bad thing.
Well, It doesn't sound very honest...
Kanchou, this meeting - to get her to reconsider - is every bit as much a fight as the gun-battles that brought us here. It's a fight that I will not lose.
She's your guest, Kongou, not a rabbit.
She is my guest, but only thanks to you. I have just this one opportunity to get her to change her mind and if I must have such a mindset to ensure success, then so be it.
Yup, there's no way this could go wrong and come back to bite you.
Hush, you.
You're holding up well, Kongou. By the time we got to the tofu I thought for sure you were going to blow up.
Yes... well. Even at home there are regional differences... She is my guest, an elder and of master-class level in her craft. No matter what her... eccentricities may be.
That's diplomatic of you. She's nothing like you were expecting, is she.
Indeed. I just wish she wouldn't use her fan to cover exchanges with the translator. It's as if she knew what I was trying to do, and is countering it.
She almost reminds me of a certain little devil that I know... But enough of that. I've spent as much time bolstering my composure as is polite, and it's time for me to rejoin my guest.
The true contest begins in earnest.
*whisper*
*whisper*
"You certainly have a big enough ship, Capitaine. I hope you don't expect me to find my own way off. Or to remember half of what I've seen."
"You also didn't bring me all the way here just so that Miss Kongou could personally give me a retirement gift."
Even if your retirement was not imminent, my gift to you would still be my gift to you, Madame. Yet it baffles me why you choose now to retire, Madame.
*whisper*
*whisper*
"You want to talk me out of it."
I wish to understand why.

Fields.MenuText: Kongou wants to talk you out of it.
If it's not prying, Madame...

Fields.DialogueText: *whisper*
"He who says nothing, consents, Capitaine. It makes me wonder who in this performance is the organ grinder and who is the monkey."
*whisper*
*whisper*
"I am told that you are counted among the most venerable of the Fleet, Miss Kongou. I'm 63 years old - more than twice your age - and I've been a designer since before you put to sea.
Unlike ships, no amount of reconstruction will extend human life. I prefer to bow out gracefully now, and let younger hands take things up when peace returns."
But you are at the top of your craft, Madame...
*whisper*
*whisper*
"Yes. Which means it would be all downhill from here. I certainly don't want that, and neither would you."
True. I also can't argue that you are past kanreki and three years into your next life. But... must fashion enter a Dark Age during the war?
And are you really at the top of your craft?
Kanchou, that is definitely uncalled for!
What I mean is, have you explored everything you can? Are you sure you're at your summit, or is there an even higher peak you haven't explored? I will bet that there is.
*whisper*
*whisper*
"I'm listening."
You haven't been a couture to a Belle before - no one has.
I'd like to hire you as couture to Kongou.
Nani?!
*whisper*
*whisper*
"You don't know what you're asking, Capitaine."
Try me.
I still wish to understand her logic, Kanchou. And, if I don't agree with it, yes - I will try to talk you out of your decision, Madame.
Madame, that is uncalled for-
Let it go, Kongou. Madame, it's also better to remain silent and be thought a fool, than to speak and remove all doubt.
*whisper*
*whisper*
"I have my answer then. I extend my apologies to you both, I didn't mean to offend."
"As to your wish, Miss Kongou, I can only give you my reasons. I can't give you the ability to understand them."
I would at least have that much.
*whisper*
"So, you are also curious, Capitaine?"
Well, even you have to admit the timing sounds a bit too convenient.
*ALARM*
... You have some time to think about it.
@BATTLE
*whisper*
*whisper*
"Spending funds on stylish clothing for your Belle... monetary resources for frivolities instead of supplies for your ship, or another."
"The rich are branded unpatriotic for flaunting their wealth that way. You and your Belle will be despised for the same reason."
The Fleet is also a shining beacon of hope to all nations who face the Morganas. Belles are both defenders and morale boosters, bar none.
There will be people who will never meet the ship, but will take pride in "their" Belle's accomplishments - and appearance - as if those things were their own.
And a treat now and then also helps boost the Belle's morale, so everyone wins.
*whisper*
*whisper*
"I spent most of the twenties fighting counterfeiters, Capitaine. Simply a garment or two for your Belle wouldn't pay enough to the seamstresses and ateliers I employ."
"And with what would I make such garments out of? The textile mills of France are manufacturing war goods now."

Fields.MenuText: Simple. Make materials part of your fee, and you'll be set.
Then is it really that out of the question to temporarily move your operation to the other side of the Atlantic?
If you're half the designer Kongou makes you out to be, I'm sure you could work miracles with khaki canvas.

Fields.DialogueText: Kongou also isn't the only Belle in the Fleet. Once word got out you cater to them, you could find yourself with more work than you know what to do with.
Going where the resources and human clients are could help with your material, business and copycat issues. You could make Montreal the Paris of the New World, you know...
I'm sure just the recommendations from Kongou alone will... Kongou?
*whisper*
*whisper*
"I'm afraid not, Capitaine. Even if I were partial to leaving my country, I've spent enough time defending the copyrights to my designs."
"I've dabbled in licensed ready-to-wear garments already, without stemming the copyists. The United States is not ready for such a concept."
I think the Fleet is. If your business is as big as you say, you could probably outfit my Belle and put my entire crew in whatever the Fleet chooses for a uniform simultaneously.
Madame, if you combine services for the Belle and her crew like that, I guarantee you'll have to beat ships off with a stick... right, Kongou? ... Kongou?
*whisper*
*whisper*
"Your ship is exaggerating, Capitaine. I may be good, but I'm not that good."
I wonder if a few yards of sailcloth could go a long way, then. What do you think, Kongou, do battleships ever get the urge to dress up as yachts? ... Um, Kongou?
Kanchou, my apologies, but I'm afraid we have kept Madame Vionnet for too long. If she is to return to Paris in a timely manner, we should not delay her departure.
Madame, it would appear that I have made a foolish blunder, and another party of guests for me to entertain is on their way. I simply can't spare any more time for you.
I see. We can at least see your guest to the gangplank, Kongou. This way Madame...
*whisper*
*whisper*
She will accompany you, Captain.
See to her safety.
If necessary, I'll guard her with my life, Miss Kongou.
@BATTLE
I hope my stewards weren't delayed. I'd like to collect them and be on our way quickly...
I see two people, so that's a good sign. Was it really necessary to see Madame Vionnet off so brusquely, Kongou? That was probably the only time you'll get to meet her.
Fashionable design is - was - her business, Kanchou. Warfare is mine. As long as Morganas keep darting about like water-borne cockroaches, I have missions to attend to.
And a running firefight with them is no place for a human woman more than twice my age.
I would believe such a thing to be no place for any human of any age.
M-madame? What...? You...can speak English.
I once worked in the House of Kate Reilly, adapting Parisian fashion to English sensibilities. But that was before your time.
I find that downplaying my linguistic ability allows me to better... survey the terrain.
Madame, why are you still here?!
I browbeat my escort into remaining here. No small feat, I will add. You have very loyal stewards, Madame Kongou.
Setting that aside, Madame, why stay?
I believe you were in the middle of negotiations, Capitaine, before we were so rudely interrupted by les Morgens.
Before we go any further, let me say that your offer is most tempting... but I have made up my mind to retire.
However, I have made a phone call. If you are not in any hurry Madame, Capitaine, I would like to introduce you to my business partner and fellow designer.
I believe your other steward will have Madame Chapsal here shortly.
She completely outfoxed me. Her first impressions, her demeanor... If not for her age, it would be humiliating.
What is it you said about able hawks and hiding talons? Hers didn't just come from age though; we should all be so lucky to stay as sharp for as long as she has.
I wish she'd gone a little easier on me... Madame Vionnet drove a hard bargain.
I'm probably going to need her to come to Lisbon eventually, to help make sure everyone at government levels is bought off on the idea.
Oh, they will, since I will make sure of it. Besides, it would be foolishness not to see the benefits a short stint in a resort-level port will make on weary crews.
It would make the Morganas think twice about setting up residence nearby too, but politics is still a thorny thing.
Then it's a good thing I left my stewards with Madame and Madame Chapsal. They can facilitate her travel.
Maybe, Kongou. Maybe not. What happens if the Fleet decides to transfer them to this Biarritz business as permanent liaisons?
Then I will trust it to them, and be satisfied with knowing that there are at least two individuals from the Fleet involved who know what they're doing.
But if you think Madame will have to help, why such an aggressive schedule to Lisbon? Not that I mind, Kanchou, but I wasn't aware of any pressing reason to stay on our current pace.
I'm hoping to get there before the supplies and equipment arrive.
Supplies? Equipment?

Fields.MenuText: ...Woops.
Certainly. Your tenmasen isn't going to build itself.
Supplies and equipment for that tenmasen you wanted.

Fields.DialogueText: Remember that tenmasen you petitioned me for? To transport VIPs around in when we're in Lisbon waters?
At least, I hope boats don't start building themselves...
Since the plan is to leave it in Lisbon, and I didn't think you'd have a problem if your Japanese boat was built abroad...
Yes, I remember.
At this rate, you're never going to get one built - much less shipped - so the plan is to build it for you in Lisbon.
That will happen when the next edition of The Complete Works of Shakespeare has a chimpanzee's name in the byline. Ships still carry boats after all.
Of course not.
Perfect. Then we just need to arrange for a workshop with storage before the stuff arrives.
I'm still don't understand, Kanchou. I never chose a boat builder, so how can anything be on the way?
I tried to speed up the process of finding candidates for you by putting the word out, to get pictures of past work from builders willing to make the trip in the first place.
Next thing I know, I'm being notified that a builder has been chosen and is on the way, along with seasoned lumber harvested from your mountain.
You still get final say in the style though, if that's all right with you.
Certainly, Kanchou! Although... it's not as important to me now; the whole process was taking so long I'd forgotten about it.
Consider it my gift, then. It's not easy to reward a lady who not only knows what she wants, but how to get it herself.
That's very kind of you. My cup already runneth over, thanks to your willingness to sail me into the heart of trouble.
That goes for the entire Fleet, Kongou.
Perhaps, but often the fastest way to reach trouble's heart is down its throat. Not everyone in the Fleet is prepared to be swallowed whole to do that.
Or crazy enough to rip out its fangs first and then be swallowed whole? Fair enough.
Then I'll go put the word out that our course to Lisbon is flexible enough to include a divert to trouble, if she raises her head.
Please do.
See you soon.
A gift, Kanchou? Your patience and thoughtfulness is a treasure to me. Wanting any more of you would be greedy.
Or would it?
